title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, where wages paid by a qualified employer are exempt from taxes for services performed during that year. A qualified employer is defined as any employer other than the United States, any State, any local government, or any instrumentality of the foregoing. The exemption under section 501 applies to qualified employers, defined as any employer except the United States, States, local governments, or their instrumentalities. A qualified individual is someone who starts employment with a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, certifies not working more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting, and is not replacing another employee unless the previous employee left voluntarily or for cause. The exemption under section 501 applies to qualified employers, defined as any employer except the United States, States, local governments, or their instrumentalities. A qualified individual is someone who starts employment with a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, certifies not working more than 40 hours in the 60-day period before starting, and is not replacing another employee unless the previous employee left voluntarily or for cause. A qualified employer may elect to have this subsection not apply. Such election shall be made in such manner as the Secretary may require. The term 'wages' shall not include any amount paid or incurred to a qualified individual during the 1-year period beginning on the hiring date of such individual by a qualified employer. The amendments made by this section exclude certain wages from qualified individuals hired by qualified employers for a 1-year period. Appropriations are made to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund to offset revenue reductions. The effective date of these amendments is specified. The amendments made by subsection (a) transfer appropriated amounts from the general fund to the Trust Fund to replicate transfers that would have occurred without the amendments. The effective date for these amendments is after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. Increases current year business credit by $1,000 for each retained worker who meets specific criteria. A retained worker is defined as a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks with wages meeting certain thresholds.
